Click on each component of the firing point to get more information.

 

For more firing point diagrams and rules for set-up refer to the following documents found via the CCO Portal:

•A-CR-CCP-177/PT-001 (Cadet Marksmanship Program Reference Manual); and

•A-CR-CCP-178/PT-001 (Cadet Biathlon Program Reference Manual).

Firing Point

Firing lane

 

The area between the firing point and target line is divided into firing lanes.   The number of firing lanes corresponds to the number of firing positions.   These lanes should be at least 1.25 metres wide.  Masking tape, trail tape or lane flags can be used to mark firing lanes at competitions.

 

Firing Point

 

The firing point is the area from which the participants fire.  For most air rifle range activities the firing point is set up with all the equipment the participant will require. The firing point should either be level or slope slightly to the rear.

Common items placed on the firing point include:

 

•Shooting mats,

•Safety glasses,

•Pellet holders, and

•Cadet air rifles.

 

 

 

Red and Green Flags

 

Every range must have a visual indicator to show when the range is active.  This is usually either a red and green flag or red and green lights. When flags are used, they are most often placed at the firing line, and on some ranges additional flags are used at access points.

 

Red = danger (active range – RSO ensures red flag/light is showing before firing starts) and

 

Green = safe (firing has ceased and the RSO has inspected all rifles at the firing point)


 

First Aid Point

 

First Aider – every cadet activity must have an identified person (qualified in Standard First Aid) available to apply first aid if required.

 

Equipment – a first aid kit must be located on the firing point. In addition, a stretcher and blanket may be required by the Range Standing Orders. Outdoor ranges could also have preventative supplies like sun screen and insect repellant.

 

Biathlon – have extra water available, and be prepared for injuries like sprains, strains and other running related injuries.
